summary:
Liesl Vivier is currently Deputy Manager of the City Development Department of the city of Almere, The Netherlands. 
Liesl graduated as an architect from the University of Cape Town (South Africa). After working in various offices in Zimbabwe and the United Kingdom, Liesl moved to the Netherlands where she followed a post graduate course in urban design at the University of Delft. She joined BDP.Khandekar in 1993 and became a partner in 2003. In 2008 she was appointed as director of the BDP studio in Rotterdam. In 2019 Liesl accepted the position of Deputy Manager of the City Development Department of the city of Almere.

Liesl has extensive experience in leading complex processes and in heading design teams for large scale projects. She has experience in, amongst others, housing developments, mixed use developments, office parks and retail.  She is the lead designer for many large scale, regeneration and new town projects in The Netherlands, such as New Town Ypenburg in The Hague, the regeneration of Amsterdam New West Centre in Amsterdam and the regeneration of Kerckebosch Housing Estate in Zeist. She has also liaised with Shyam Khandekar on a number of projects in India. 

Liesl has experience in both the private and the public sector. In The Netherlands, Liesl has been appointed as supervisor over a number of urban design projects, where she liaises with architects and landscape architects during the realisation phase of designs.

profile_positions.description:
Director and studio leader of BDP Khandekar, the multidisciplinarary BDP studio in The Netherlands. 

Projects

Revitalisation of Dronten Station Area, The Netherlands. 
2008 until the present
A Masterplan to revitalise a 50 hectare light industrial park next to Dronten Station, with the aim of converting this area into a new mixed use station quarter. 
Role undertaken: Design leader for the masterplan phase. Member of the quality team, whose role is to monitor the design quality of the masterplan during the implementation phase. 

Christchurch, Avon River Precinct, North Frame, East Frame Christchurch New Zealand
An extensive scheme to rebuild the City of Christchurch following catastrophic damage inflicted on the city centre in 2010 and 2011. BDP has been appointed to redesign the River Corridor, The North Frame and the East Frame. Liesl is mainly involved in the 12 hectare East Frame site, which will become a new residential quarter for the city. 
Value of Project: Public Realm associated with Avon River Corridor and East Frame NZ $100M).
Role undertaken: BDP is leading the overall design and engineering team in association with the NZ engineering consultancy Opus International Consulting. Liesl Vivier is leading the Urban Design group within the wider design team.
Period worked on project: 2013

Station Area Bilthoven, The Netherlands
A design to upgrade the station area and town centre of Bilthoven into an attractive, pedestrian orientated centre. . 
Role undertaken: Lead designer for the multidiscplinirary design team, Liesl is currently appointed by the city council as design supervisor, where she monitosr the quality of all design work undertaken in the town cenre.
Period worked on project: 2008 to present
profile_positions.title: Director

profile_positions.description:
In 2003,  Liesl became a partner in Khandekar Stadsontwerp en Landschapsarchitectuur. As a Partner Liesl assisted Shyam Khandekar with the day-to-day management of the company besides acting as lead designer for a wide variety of urban design projects. 

Projects:

Stationspark, Oldenzaal, The Netherlands
A regeneration scheme for the station area and surroundings of Oldenzaal. 35 hectares of light industry will be transformed into a new quarter for living and working. The project is currently under construction.
Role undertaken : Lead designer for the vision-document, masterplan document and design codes. Liesl is appointed by the City Council as supervisor of the scheme.
Period worked on Project: 2003 until the present

Amsterdam New West, Centre, The Netherlands
A regeneration scheme for the revitalisation of the 35 hectare New West Centre of Amsterdam. Role undertaken: Design leader for the competition phase. Design leader for the Masterplan and design leader for various part-plans within the masterplan. Liesl is appointed by the City Council as a supervisor of the masterplan. 
Period worked on Project: 2005 until the present

This residential design for a 50 hectare site bordering of the town of Zeist provides for the development of 1 250 residences in a forested area.  
Role undertaken: As design leader, Liesl liaised extensively with residents in workshops and through public consultation, to come up with a design solution for this environmentally sensitive area. 
Period worked on project: 2005 to present. Currently the first phase of this project is under construction.
profile_positions.title: Partner

profile_positions.description:
After graduating from The University of Delft, The Netherlands, Liesl joined Khandekar Stadsontwerp en Landschapsarchitectuur where she worked as an urban designer on many projects of varying size and scale. 

Projects:

Ypenburg, the Hague, The Netherlands
Competition winning residential project for 400 housing units where every garden borders onto water. 
Role undertaken: Liesl acted as lead designer of the multidischiplinary team. She also liased with the architects, traffic engineers and other consultants, to create this unique new housing quarter. The project has been completed
Period worked on project: 1998 to 2005.
profile_positions.title: Urban Designer
